  k10 = k3 × k7 – 18

and since
  k9 = 467  and  k10 = 514,

we immediately have

  k9 = k10 – 47   (because 514 – 47 = 467).

That is, one very simple formula for k9 is

  (1)  k9 = k10 – 47.

In addition, since k10 itself equals k3×k7 – 18, we may also write

  (2)  k9 = (k3 × k7 – 18) – 47 = k3 × k7 – 65.

There is also an alternative expression given in the text. In particular, it was noted that
  467 = k6×9 + 26,
so if we set

  (3)  k9 = 9 × k6 + 26,

then one must have k6 = (467 – 26)/9 = 441/9 = 49. In other words, if it turns out that key k6 is 49 then we can write

  (3′)  k9 = 9 × 49 + 26.

A few comments:

• The number 47 appears as the difference between k10 and k9 (i.e. k9 = k10 – 47). In addition, it is noted that 47 itself shows up in another formula (namely “k8×47+16” which equals k14) so that the prime 47 has a special role.

• Notice also that 26 factors as 2×13; this may be an indication that there is some hidden structure or pattern among these keys (perhaps many of them are built from primes).

To answer the questions explicitly:

1. Can k9 be expressed as k10 – 47? 
  Yes, since 514 – 47 = 467 we have
   k9 = k10 – 47.

2. What does 47 relate to?
  It appears both as the difference between k10 and k9 and in another formula (such as “k8×47+16” which is said to equal k14). Also, it is a prime number and seems chosen deliberately.

3. Is 467 = some_key × M + C? 
  Yes; one natural example is the expression
   467 = 9 × k6 + 26,
which works provided k6 = 49 (since 9×49+26 = 441+26 = 467). In this representation the constant 26 factors as 2×13, suggesting a pattern.

4. Find the SIMPLEST formula for k9.
  There are at least two “simple” forms:
  • Using k10: k9 = k10 – 47.
  • Or using k3 and k7: k9 = (k3×k7 – 18) – 47 = k3×k7 – 65.
  Which one is simplest depends on which keys you already know. Often the direct difference
   k9 = k10 – 47
is the most straightforward.

In summary, a very acceptable answer is to note that

  k9 = k10 – 47  or equivalently  k9 = (k3×k7 – 18) – 47 = k3×k7 – 65,

and one may also write
  k9 = 9 × k6 + 26  (with k6 = 49).

Any of these forms is “simple” enough, and the appearance of the prime 47 (and its occurrence in other formulas) suggests that it was chosen for a reason.
